Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanobiology of Microbubble Induced Cellular Injury in the Pulmonary System

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0747760, Ghadiali

Microbubble flows are an important area of research in the biomedical sciences. Important applications of microbubbles include the enhancement of ultrasound images, drug delivery and cancer treatment. However, microbubbles can also cause significant cellular and tissue damage in the cardiopulmonary system. For example, patients suffering from acute lung injury (AcLI) cannot breathe on their own due to the collapse and fluid occlusion of small pulmonary airways. These patients must be placed on a mechanical ventilator in order to survive. However, the microbubbles generated during ventilation can exacerbate the existing lung injury. As a result, the mortality rate for AcLI is very high (30-40%). Microbubbles have been shown to impart complex fluid mechanical forces to the epithelial cells (EpC) which line airway walls. Depending on the EpC's biophysical properties, these forces may result in cell death and disruption of the epithelium. In addition, these fluid mechanical forces may also be transduced into injurious biological responses including the up-regulation of inflammatory pathways and altered surfactant secretion. However, the exact mechanisms responsible for microbubble induced cellular injury in the pulmonary system are not known. The research objective of this CAREER project is to use a combination of computational and experimental techniques from the biological, engineering and mathematical sciences to fill this knowledge gap.

The PI will develop multi-scale, fluid-structure computational models of cellular deformation and detachment during microbubble flows. These models will be used to quantify mechanical parameters which are difficult to measure experimentally (i.e. cell deformation). The PI will also utilize an in-vitro, microfluidic cell culture system and sophisticated microscopy techniques to ascertain the biological response of EpCs to microbubble flows (i.e. protein expression). The correlation of computational and experimental results will be use to identify the biomechanical mechanisms responsible for microbubble induced cellular injury. The significance of this research is that once we understand the mechanisms responsible for cellular injury, this information can be used to develop novel pharmaco-protective therapies for AcLI that minimize ventilation induced lung injury by altering specific cellular and/or molecular properties.

The main educational objective of this proposal is to develop a bioengineering workforce that not only understands the interaction between engineering and biological systems but can also translate this knowledge into commercially viable and life-saving medical products. The PI will collaborate with local medical device companies to solve real-world design issues and will play a key role in developing industrially sponsored bioengineering projects within Lehigh University's Integrated Product Development program. As a part of this program, the PI will advise multi-disciplinary student teams who will work closely with their industry sponsor to develop design plans and prototypes that satisfy technical, business and regulatory requirements. These hands-on, industrially sponsored projects will provide students with the team-work skills most valued by employers and first-hand knowledge of the complex issues involved in developing commercially viable and life-saving medical products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acute lung injury (ALI) is a devastating disease that involves rapid deterioration of lung function and an out-of-control inflammatory response that spreads from the lung to other organs. Currently, the only effective way to treat patients with ALI is to place them on a mechanical ventilator. These ventilators force air into the diseased lungs and can help restore oxygenation. Unfortunately, the forcing of air into a lung filled with fluid generates microbubbles of air within the lungs’ airways. These microbubbles can cause significant cellular and tissue damage and additional lung inflammation. This exacerbation of the existing lung injury lead to very high mortality rates (30-40%) and ALI kills more people than breast and prostate cancer combined. Although a number of investigators have attempted to find ways to prevent the formation of microbubbles during ventilation, this has proven to be a difficult if not impossible task. As part of this NSF CAREER grant, we have taken a different approach to this problem where novel changes in the material/mechanical properties of lung cells are used to minimize the damaging effect of microbubbles in the lung. There were two main goals: 1. Identify the biomechanical mechanisms responsible for microbubble-induced cellular injury and 2. Identify the mechanisms by which microbubbles activate inflammatory signaling within lung epithelial cells. The intellectual merit of this research is that once we understand the mechanisms responsible for microbubble-induced injury and inflammation, this information can be used to develop novel pharmaco-protective therapies that minimize the amount of injury and inflammation caused by microbubbles flows during mechanical ventilation.

The studies performed in this NSF CAREER grant used computational and experimental techniques to both identify mechanisms and make predictions about what types of changes in cellular mechanics could be used to minimize microbubble-induced injury. We have tested these predictions experimentally using in-vitro micro-fluidic devices that mimic the structure of the pulmonary system. Due to space limitations, I only describe the two highest impact outcomes of this research below.

1. The physical damage caused by microbubbles can be prevented by altering the mechanical properties of lung epithelial cells. In-vitro micro-fluidic devices and engineering tools were used to demonstrate that microbubbles can both kill lung epithelial cells and disrupt the layer of cells that normally keep fluid out of lung airspaces. Sophisticated computational tools were then used to simulate microbubble-induced cellular injury and make predictions about how to prevent this injury. Computational results indicated that altering the cell’s internal structure so that it acts like a viscous fluid (fluidization) would lead to less microbubble-induced injury. Experiments that altered the cell internal structure with chemical agents confirmed that “fluidization” does results in less cell death and damage during microbbuble flows. We are currently translating this basic science knowledge into a clinically useful therapeutic. Specifically, a commerically available pharmaceutical compound is being used to make similar changes in cell mechanics/structure and we are using both in-vitro and in-vivo techniques to test the efficacy of this compound. Therefore, the broader impact of the basic science information obtained in the NSF grant is that it is leading to a new way to treat acute lung injury with a pharmaceutical compound that minimizes the physical injury caused by microbubbles during mechanical ventilation.
